bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 8, 1929

div1.p: Carter writes that she spent time with Frost in Baltimore going over references and describes the Johns Hopkins University Commemoration Day exercises that she attended.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 8, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report. (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
February 26, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I did not have a chance to write to you last week, as I
went to Baltimore on Thursday, to stay with the Frost's, and re-
mained over the week-end. I took all my remaining material in
connection with the History of Yellow Fever: MS. bibliographic
cards, books which I thought Frost would wish to see etc. etc. Did
no routine work with him, however, although we had two very satisfactory
talks, during the latter of which he, to some extent, went over my re-
maining file of bibliographic references, nearly all of which were
verified long since and are now mainly recast and retyped for his
greater convenience. Dr. Frost told me that I had been doing “good
work.” That it is good work, is due as much to Miss Brown as to
myself, however. She is devoted and indefatigable.

Dr. Frost also told me that he hoped to be able to again
take up the final editing of Father's MS intensively about the middle
of March and added that he would have no use for my material in the
interim. I therefor brought it all back with me and will continue
to still further work up the bibliographic cards as, although all of
the essential ones have been verified (and nearly all of the others)
I can still do a good deal to make them clearer, thus expediting Dr.
Frost's work when he resumes, it. Also, so long as there is any time
remaining we want to clear up everything we possibly can in the way of
references, even if not essential. Indeed, Miss Brown, by dint of
practically reading several old Spanish books from cover to cover,
“tracked down” three verbatim quotations while I was in Baltimore. A

I wish that you could have been present at the Hopkins Commemora-
tion Day exercises on February 22nd. Dr. Welch delivered the principal
address, so it is needless to say that we enjoyed ourselves! The re-
ception and luncheon at Homewood, a tea at the Howell's and a dinner
at the Frost's that night completed the most festive day I've spent
in a very long time, and one thoroughly delightful and worth-while.
Still, I am more than glad to be “back on the job,” as I am too con-
cerned with its completion to be willing to stay away from actual work
[unclear], save when, as in my recent trip, future plans have to be dis-
cussed and our subsequent energies adapted accordingly.

With all manner of good wishes and hoping much that when next
you start South you will get as far as Washington,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
